titleStmt.title: THE TRAGEDY OF King Richard the third. Containing, His treacherous Plots against his brother Clarence: the pittiefull murther of his iunocent nephewes: his tyrannicall vsurpation: with the whole course of his detested life, and most deserued death. As it hath beene lately Acted by the Right honourable the Lord Chamberlaine his seruants.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by Valentine Sims, for Andrew Wise, dwelling in Paules Chuch-yard, at the Signe of the Angell.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. King Edward IV Duke of Buckingham Earl of Richmond Cecily Neville, Duchess of York, mother of Edward IV, Clarence, Richard III Lady Anne Neville/wife of Edward, Prince of Wales/later Duchess of Gloucester Duke of Gloucester/Richard III Lord Richard Gray Lord Rivers Queen Elizabeth Woodville, wife of Edward IV, mother of the 2 Princes Queen Margaret, wife of Henry VI Richard Duke of York Edward young Prince of Wales George, Duke of Clarence Marquess of Dorset, Queen's son by first marriage Sir William Catesby Lord Hastings Duke of Norfolke Bishop of Exeter Lord Mayor of London Richard Ratcliffe Lord Stanley, Earl of Derby James Tyrrell Robert Brokenbury Multiple Speakers Cardinal Bishop of Ely First Citizen Second Citizen Third Citizen Clarence's son Clarence's daughter First Executioner Second Executioner Servant carrying hearse Gentleman accompanying hearse Another Boy telling Richard about Tyrell Messenger from Stanley to Hastings Ghost of Prince Edward, son of Henry VI Scrivener First Lord/Oxford Second Lord/Herbert Third Lord/Blunt Pursuivant named Hastings Sir Christopher/pursuivant first messenger to Richard second messenger to Richard third messenger to Richard fourth messenger to Richard Ghost of Henry VI Ghost of Vaughan

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following

div2.stage: Enter Richard Duke of Glocester solus.

sp.l: NOw is the winter of our discontent,
Made glorious summer by this son of York:
And all the clouds that lowered upon our house,
In the deep bosom of the Ocean buried.
Now are our brows bound with victorious wreathes,
Our bruised arms hung up for monuments,
Our stern alarms changed to merry meetings,
Our dreadful marches to delightful measures.
Grim visaged war, hath smoothed his wrinkled front,
And now instead of mounting barbed steeds,
To fright the souls of fearful adversaries.
He capers nimbly in a Ladies chamber,
To the lascivious pleasing of a love.
But I that am not shaped for sportive tricks,
Nor made to court an amorous looking-glass,
I that am rudely stamped and want loves majesty,
To strut before a wanton ambling Nymph:
I that am curtailed of this fair proportion,
Cheated of feature by dissembling nature,
Deformed, unfinished, sent before my time
Into this breathing world scarce half made up,
And that so lamely and unfashionable,
That dogs bark at me as I halt by them:
Why I in this weak piping time of peace
Have no delight to pass away the time,
Unless to spy my shadow in the sun,
And descant on mine own deformity:
And therefore since I cannot prove a lover
To entertain these fair well spoken days.
I am determined to prove a villain,
And hate the idle pleasures of these days:
Plots have I laid inductious dangerous,
By drunken Prophesies, libels and dreams,
To set my brother Clarence and the King
In deadly hate the one against the other.
And if King Edward be as true and just,
As I am subtle, false, and treacherous:
This day should Clarence closely be mewed up,
About a Prophecy which says that G.
Of Edwards heirs the murtherers shall be.
Dive thoughts down to my soul,
sp.stage: Enter Clarence with a gard of men.
sp.l: Here Clarence comes,
Brother, good days, what means this armed guard
That waits upon your grace?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: His Majesty tendering my persons safety hath appointed
This conduct to convey me to the tower.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Upon what cause?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Because my name is George.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Alack my Lord that fault is none of yours,
He should for that commit your Godfathers:
O belike his Majesty hath some intent
That you shall be new christened in the Tower.
But whats the matter Clarence may I know?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Yea Richard when I know; for I protest
As yet I do not, but as I can learn,
He hearkens after Prophecies and dreams,
And from the cross-row plucks the letter G:
And says a wizard told him that by G,
His issue disinherited should be.
And for my name of George begins with G,
It follows in his thought that I am he.
These as I learn and such like toys as these,
Have moved his highness to commit me now.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why this it is when men are ruled by women,
It is not the King that sends you to the tower,
My Lady Gray his wife, Clarence it is she,
That tempers him to this extremity,
Was it not she and that good man of worship
Anthony Wooduile her brother there,
That made him send Lord Hastings to the tower;
From whence this present day he is delivered?
We are not safe Clarence, we are not safe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: By heaven I think there is no man is secured,
But the Queen's kindred and night-walking Heralds,
That trudge betwixt the King and Mistress Shore,
Heard ye not what an humble suppliant
Lord Hastings was to her for his delivery.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Humbly complaining to her deity,
Got my Lord Chamberlain his liberty.
I will tell you what, I think it is our way,
If we will keep in favour with the King,
To be her men and wear her livery.
The jealous overworn widow and herself,
Since that our brother dubbed them gentlewomen,
Are mighty gossips in this monarchy.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I beseech your Graces both to pardon me:
His Majesty hath straightly given in charge,
That no man shall have private conference,
Of what degree soever with his brother.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Even so if it please your worship Brokenbury,
You may partake of anything we say:
We speak no treason man, we say the King
Is wise and virtuous, and his noble Queen
Well stroke in years, fair and not jealous.
We say that Shores wife hath a pretty foot,
A cherry lip, a bonny eye, a passing pleasing tongue:
And that the Queen's kindred are made gentlefolks.
How say you sir, can you deny all this?

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: With this (my Lord) myself have naught to do.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Naught to do with Mistress Shore, I tell thee fellow,
He that doth naught with her, excepting one
Were best he do it secretly alone.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I beseech your Grace to pardon me, and withal forbear
Your conference with the noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: We know thy charge Brokenbury and will obey,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: We are the Queen's abjects and must obey.
Brother farewell, I will unto the King,
And whatsoever you will employ me in,
Were it to call King Edwards widow sister,
I will perform it to enfranchise you,
Mean time this deep disgrace in brotherhood,
Touches me deeper than you can imagine.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I know it pleaseth neither of us well:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Well, your imprisonment shall not be long,
I will deliver you or lie for you,
Mean time have patience.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I must perforce; farewell. Exit Clar.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go tread the path that thou shalt never return,
Simple plain Clarence I do love thee so,
That I will shortly send thy soul to heaven,
If heaven will take the present at our hands:
But who comes here the new delivered hastings?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: Good time of day unto my gracious Lord:

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: As much unto my good Lord Chamberlain:
Well are you welcome to the open air,
How hath your Lordship brooked imprisonment?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: With patience (noble Lord) as prisoners must:
But I shall live my Lord to give them thanks
That were the cause of my imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt, and so shall Clarence too,
For they that were your enemies are his,
And have prevailed as much on him as you.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: More pity that the Eagle should be mewed,
While kites and buzzards prey at liberty.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What news abroad?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: No news so bad abroad as this at home:
The King is sickly, weak and melancholy,
And his Physicians fear him mightily.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Now by Saint Paul this news is bad indeed,
O he hath kept an evil diet long,
And overmuch consumed his royal person,
It is very grievous to be thought upon:
What is he in his bed?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go you before and I will follow you.
He cannot live I hope, and must not die,
Till George be packed with post horse up to heaven.
I will in to urge his hatred more to Clarence,
With lies well steeled with weighty arguments,
And if I fail not in my deep intent,
Clarence hath not an other day to live
Which done, God take King Edward to his mercy,
And leave the world for me to bustle in,
For then I will marry Warwick's youngest daughter:
What though I killed her husband and her father,
The readiest way to make the wench amends,
Is to become her husband and her father:
The which will I, not all so much for love,
As for another secret close intent.
By marrying her which I must reach unto.
But yet I run before my horse to market:
Clarence still breathes, Edward still lives and reigns,
When they are gone then must I count my gains.

div2.stage: Enter Lady Anne with the hearse of Harry the 6.

sp.speaker: Lady An.
sp.l: Set down set down your honourable Lord
If honour may be shrouded in a hearse,
Whilst I a while obsequiously lament
The untimely fall of virtuous Lancaster:
Poor key-cold figure of a holy King,
Pale ashes of the house of Lancaster,
Thou bloodless remnant of that royal blood,
Be it lawful that I invocate thy ghost,
To hear the lamentations of poor Anne,
Wife to thy Edward, to thy slaughtered son,
Stabbed by the selfsame hands that made these holes,
Lo in those windows that let forth thy life,
I pour the helpless balm of my poor eyes,
Cursed be the hand that made these fatal holes,
Cursed be the heart that had the heart to do it.
More direful hap betide that hated wretch,
That makes us wretched by the death of thee:
Than I can wish to adders, spiders, toads,
Or any creeping venomed thing that lives.
If ever he have child abortive be it,
Prodigious and untimely brought to light:
Whose ugly and unnatural aspect,
May fright the hopeful mother at the view.
If ever he have wife, let her be made
As miserable by the death of him,
As I am made by my poor Lord and thee.
Come now towards Chertsey with your holy load,
Taken from Paul's to be interred there:
And still as you are weary of the weight,
Rest you whiles I lament King Henry's corse.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Stay you that bear the corse and set it down.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What black magician conjures up this fiend,
To stop devoted charitable deeds.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Villain set down the corse, or by Saint. Pall,
I will make a corse of him that disobeys.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Lord, stand back and let the coffin pass.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Unmannered dog, stand thou when I command,
Advance thy halberd higher than my breast,
Or by Saint Paul I will strike thee to my foot,
And spurn upon thee beggar for thy boldness.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What do you tremble, are you all afraid?
Alas, I blame you not, for you are mortal,
And mortal eyes cannot endure the devil.
Avaunt thou dreadful minister of hell,
Thou hadst but power over his mortal body,
His soul thou canst not have, therefore be gone.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sweet Saint, for Charity be not so cursed.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Foul Devil, for Gods sake hence and trouble us not,
For thou hast made the happy earth thy hell:
Filled it with cursing cries and deep exclaims.
If thou delight to view thy heinous deeds,
Behold this pattern of thy butcheries.
O gentlemen see, see dead Henry's wounds,
Open their congealed mouths and bleed afresh.
Blush blush thou lump of foul deformity,
For it is thy presence that exhales this blood,
From cold and empty veins where no blood dwells.
Thy deed inhumane and unnatural,
Provokes this deluge most unnatural.
O God which this blood madest, revenge his death,
O earth which this blood drinkest, revenge his death:
Either heaven with lightning strike the murtherer dead,
Or earth gape open wide and eat him quick.
As thou doest swallow up this good Kings blood,
Which his hell-governed arm hath butchered.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Lady you know no rules of charity,
Which renders good for bad, blessings for curses.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.l: Villain thou knowest no law of God nor man:
No beast so fierce but knows some touch of pity.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But I know none, and therefore am no beast.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O wonderful when Devils tell the troth.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: More wonderful when Angels are so angry
Vouchsafe divine perfection of a woman,
Of these supposed evils to give me leave,
By circumstance but to acquit myself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Vouchsafe defused infection of a man,
For these known evils but to give me leave,
By circumstance to curse thy cursed self.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Fairer than tongue can name thee, let me have
Some patient leisure to excuse myself.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Fouler than heart can think thee thou canst make
No excuse currant but to hang thyself.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: By such despair I should accuse myself.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: And by despairing shouldst thou stand excused,
For doing worthy vengeance on thyself,
Which didst unworthy slaughter upon others.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Say that I slew them not.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then they are not dead,
But dead they are, and devilish slave by thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I did not kill your husband.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why then he is alive.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nay, he is dead, and slain by Edwards hand.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: In thy foul throat thou liest, Queen Margaret saw
Thy bloody falchion smoking in his blood,
The which thou once didst bend against her breast,
But that thy brothers beat aside the point.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I was provoked by her slanderous tongue,
Which laid their guilt upon my guiltless shoulders.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou wast provoked by thy bloody mind,
Which never dreamt on aught but butcheries,
Didst thou not kill this King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I grant yea.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Doest grant me hedgehog then god grant me too
Thou mayst be damned for that wicked deed,
O he was gentle, mild, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The fitter for the King of Heaven that hath him.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: He is in heaven where thou shalt never come.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Let him thank me that helped to send him thither,
For he was fitter for that place than earth,

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: And thou unfit for any place but hell.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yes one place else if you will hear me name it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Some dungeon.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Your bedchamber.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Ill rest betide the chamber where thou liest.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So will it Madam till I lie with you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I hope so.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I know so, but gentle Lady Anne,
To leave this keen encounter of our wits,
And fall somewhat into a slower method:
Is not the causer of the timeless deaths,
Of these Plantagenets Henry and Edward,
As blameful as the executioner.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Thou art the cause and most accursed effect.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Your beauty was the cause of that effect,
Your beauty which did haunt me in my sleep:
To undertake the death of all the world
So I might rest one hour in your sweet bosom.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: If I thought that I tell thee homicide,
These nails should rend that beauty from my cheeks.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: These eyes could never endure sweet beauties wrack,
You should not blemish them if I stood by:
As all the world is cheered by the son,
So I by that, it is my day, my life.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Black night overshade thy day, and death thy life.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Curse not thyself fair creature, thou art both.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would I were to be revenged on thee.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is a quarrel most unnatural,
To be revenged on him that loveth you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is a quarrel just and reasonable,
To be revenged on him that slew my husband.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He that bereft thee Lady of thy husband,
Did it to help thee to a better husband.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: His better doth not breath upon the earth.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Go to, he lives that loves you better than he could.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Name him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Plantagenet.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Why that was he.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The selfsame name but one of better nature.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Where is he.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Here.
Why doest thou spit at me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Would it were mortal poison for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Never came poison from so sweet a place.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Never hung poison on a fouler toad,
Out of my sight thou doest infect my eyes.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Thine eyes sweet Lady have infected mine.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Would they were basilisks to strike thee dead.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I would they were that I might die at once,
For now they kill me with a living death:
Those eyes of thine from mine have drawn salt tears,
Shamed their aspect with store of childish drops:
I never sued to friend nor enemy,
My tongue could never learn sweet soothing words:
But now thy beauty is proposed my fee:
My proud heart sues and prompts my tongue to speak,
Teach not thy lips such scorn, for they were made
For kissing Lady not for such contempt.
If thy revengeful heart cannot forgive,
Lo here I lend thee this sharpe pointed sword:
Which if thou please to hide in this true bosom,
And let the soul forth that adoreth thee:
I lay it naked to the deadly stroke,
And humbly beg the death upon my knee.
Nay, do not pause, it was I that killed your husband,
But it was thy beauty that provoked me:
Nay now dispatch it was I that killed King Henry:
But it was thy heavenly face that set me on:
sp.stage: Here she lets fall the sword.
sp.l: Take up the sword again or take up me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Arise dissembler, though I wish thy death,
I will not be the executioner.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then bid me kill myself, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I have already.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Tush that was in thy rage:
Speak it again, and even with the word,
That hand which for thy love did kill thy love,
Shall for thy love, kill a far truer love:
To both their deaths shalt thou be accessory.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I would I knew thy heart.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is figured in my tongue.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: I fear me both are false.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then never was man true.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: Well, well, put up your sword.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Say then my peace is made.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: That shall you know hereafter.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But shall I live in hope.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: All men I hope live so.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Vouchsafe to wear this ring.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: To take is not to give.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Look how this ring encompasseth thy finger,
Even so thy breast encloseth my poor heart.
Wear both of them for both of them are thine,
And if thy poor devoted suppliant may
But beg one favour at thy gracious hand,
Thou doest confirm his happiness for ever.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: What is it?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: That it would please thee leave these sad designs,
To him that hath more cause to be a mourner,
And presently repair to Crosbie place,
Where after I have solemnly interred
At Chertsie monastery this noble King,
And wet his grave with my repentant tears,
I will with all expedient duty see you:
For divers unknown reasons, I beseech you
Grant me this boon.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: With all my heart, and much it joys me too,
To see you are become so penitent:
Tressill and Barkley go along with me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Bid me farewell.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: It is more than you deserve:
But since you teach me how to flatter you,
Imagine I have said farewell already.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sirs take up the corse.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Towards Chertsie noble Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No, to white Friars there attend my coming.
Was ever woman in this humour wooed,
Was ever woman in this humour won:
I will have her, but I will not keep her long.
What I that killed her husband and his father,
To take her in her hearts extremest hate:
With curses in her mouth, tears in her eyes,
The bleeding witness of her hatred by,
Having God, her conscience, and these bars against me:
And I nothing to back my suite at all,
But the plain Devil and dissembling looks,
And yet to win her all the world to nothing. Ha
Hath she forgot already that brave Prince
Edward, her Lord whom I some three months since,
Stabbed in my angry mood at Tewxbery,
A sweeter and a lovelier gentleman,
Framed in the prodigality of nature:
Young, valiant, wise, and no doubt right royal,
The spacious world cannot again afford:
And will she yet debase her eyes on me
That cropped the golden prime of this sweet Prince,
And made her widow to a woeful bed,
On me whose all not equals Edwards moiety,
On me that halt, and am unshapen thus.
My Dukedom to a beggarly denier.
I do mistake my person all this while,
Upon my life she finds, although I cannot
Myself, to be a marvelous proper man.
I will be at charges for a looking glass,
And entertain some score or two of tailors,
To study fashions to adorn my body,
Since I am crept in favour with myself,
I will maintain it with some little cost:
But first I will turn yon fellow in his grave,
And then return lamenting to my love.
Shine out fair sun till I have bought a glass,
That I may see my shadow as I pass.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Have patience Madam, there is no doubt his Majesty
Will soon recover his accustomed health.

sp.speaker: Gray
sp.l: In that you brooke it, ill it makes him worse,
Therefore for Gods sake entertain good comfort,
And cheer his grace quick and merry words,

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If he were dead what would betide of me.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: No other harm but loss of such a Lord.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The loss of such a Lord includes all harm.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: The heavens have blessed you with a goodly son,
To be your comforter when he is gone.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O he is young, and his minority
Is put unto the trust of Rich. Glocester,
A man that loves not me nor none of you.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Is it concluded he shall be protector?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: It is determined, not concluded yet,
But so it must be if the King miscarry.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: Here come the Lords of Buckingham and Darby.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Good time of day unto your royal grace.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: God make your Majesty joyful as you have been.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: The Countess Richmond good my Lord of Darby,
To your good prayers will scarcely say, Amen:
Yet Darby notwithstanding, she is your wife,
And loves not me, be you good Lord assured
I hate not you for her proud arrogance.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: I do beseech you either not believe
The envious slanders of her false accusers,
Or if she be accused in true report,
Bear with her weakness which I think proceeds
From wayward sickness, and no grounded malice.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: Saw you the King today, my Lord of Darby?

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: But now the Duke of Buckingham and I
Came from visiting his Majesty.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: With likelihood of his amendment Lords?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Madam good hope, his Grace speaks cheerfully.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: God grant him health, did you confer with him.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Madam we did: He desires to make atonement
Betwixt the Duke of Glocester and your brothers,
And betwixt them and my Lord chamberlain,
And sent to warn them to his royal presence.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Would all were well, but that will never be.
I fear our happiness is at the highest.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: They do me wrong and I will not endure it,
Who are they that complains unto the King,
That I forsooth am stern and love them not:
By holy Paul they love his grace but lightly,
That fill his ears with such dissentious rumours:
Because I cannot flatter and speak fair,
Smile in men's faces, smooth, deceive and cog,
Duck with french nods and apish courtesy,
I must be held a rancorous enemy.
Cannot a plain man live and think no harm,
But thus his simple truth must be abused,
By silken sly insinuating jacks?

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: To whom in all this presence speaks your Grace?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To thee that hast nor honesty nor grace,
When have I injured thee, when done thee wrong,
Or thee or thee or any of your faction:
A plague upon you all. His royal person
(Whom God preserve better than you would wish)
Cannot be quiet scarce abreathing while,
But you must trouble him with lewd complaints.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Brother of Glocester, you mistake the matter:
The King of his own royal disposition,
And not provoked by any suitor else,
Aiming belike at your interior hatred,
Which in your outward actions shows itself,
Against my kindred, brother, and myself:
Makes him to send that thereby he may gather
The ground of your ill will and to remove it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I cannot tell, the world is grown so bad
That wrens make prey where Eagles dare not perch,
Since every Jack became a Gentleman:
There is many a gentle person made a Jack.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come come, we know your meaning brother Gloucester.
You envy my advancement and my friends,
God grant we never may have need of you.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Mean time God grants that we have need of you,
Our brother is imprisoned by your means,
Myself disgraced, and the nobility
Held in contempt, whilst many fair promotions,
Are daily given to ennoble those
That scarce some two days since were worth a noble.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: By him that raised me to this careful height,
From that contented hap which I enjoyed,
I never did incense his Majesty
Against the Duke of Clarence: but have been,
An earnest advocate to plead for him.
My Lord you do me shameful injury,
Falsely to draw me in these vile suspects.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: You may deny that you were not the cause,
Of my Lord Hastings late imprisonment.

sp.speaker: Ryu.
sp.l: She may my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: She may Lord Ryuers, why who knows not so?
She may do more Sir than denying that:
She may help you to many fair preferments,
And then deny her aiding hand therein,
And lay those honours on your high deserts,
What may she not, she may, yea marry may she.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: What marry may she.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What marry may she, marry with a King,
A bachelor, a handsome stripling too.
Iwis your Grandam had a worser match.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My Lord of Glocester, I have too long borne
Your blunt upbraidings and your bitter scoffs,
By heaven I will acquaint his Majesty
With those gross taunts I often have endured:
I had rather be a country servant maid,
Than a great Queen with this condition,
To be thus taunted, scorned, and baited at:
Small joy have I in being Englands Queen.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mar.
sp.l: And lessened be that small, God I beseech thee,
Thy honour, state, and seat is due to me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What? threat you me with telling of the King,
Tell him and spare not, look what I have said,
I will avouch in presence of the King:
It is time to speak, my pains are quite forgot.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mar.
sp.l: Out devil I remember them too well,
Thou slewest my husband Henry in the tower,
And Edward my poor son at Teuxbery.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ere you were Queen, yea or your husband King.
I was a packhorse in his great affairs,
A weeder out of his proud adversaries,
A liberal rewarder of his friends:
To royalize his blood I spilt mine own.

sp.speaker: Qu. Mar.
sp.l: Yea and much better blood than his or thine.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: In all which time you and your husband Gray,
Were factious for the house of Lancaster:
And Ryuers, so were you, was not your husband
In Margaret's battle at Saint Albones slain:
Let me put in your minds, if yours forget
What you have been ere now, and what you are.
Withal, what I have been, and what I am.

sp.speaker: Qu. Ma.
sp.l: A murtherous villain, and so still thou art.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Poor Clarence did forsake his father Warwicke,
Yea and forswore himself (which Jesu pardon.)

sp.speaker: Qu. Ma.
sp.l: Which God revenge.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: To fight on Edwards party for the crown,
And for his meed poor Lord: he is mewed up:
I would to God my heart were flint like Edwards,
Or Edwards soft and pitiful like mine,
I am too childish, foolish for this world.

sp.speaker: Qu. Ma.
sp.l: Hie thee to hell for shame and leave the world
Thou Cacodemon, there thy kingdom is.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: My Lord: of Glocester in those busy days,
Which here you urge to prove us enemies,
We followed then our Lord: our lawful King,
So should we you if you should be our King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: If I should be? I had rather be a peddler,
Far be it from my heart the thought of it.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: As little joy my Lord as you suppose
You should enjoy, were you this countries King,
As little joy may you suppose in me,
That I enjoy being the Queen thereof.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: A little joy enjoys the Queen thereof,
For I am she and altogether joyless.
I can no longer hold me patient:
Hear me you wrangling Pirates that fall out,
In sharing that which you have piled from me:
Which of you trembles not that looks on me?
If not, that I being Queen you bow like subjects,
Yet that by you deposed you quake like rebels:
O gentle villain do not turn away.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Foul wrinkled witch what makest thou in my sight?

sp.speaker: Q. Ma.
sp.l: But repetition of what thou hast marred,
That will I make before I let thee go:
A husband and a son thou owest to me,
And thou a kingdom, all of you allegiance:
The sorrow that I have by right is yours,
And all the pleasures you usurp are mine.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: The curse my noble father laid on thee,
When thou didst crown his warlike brows with paper,
And with thy scorn drewst riuers from his eyes,
And then to dry them gavest the Duke a clout,
Steeped in the faultless blood of pretty Rutland:
His curses then from bitterness of soul
Denounced, against thee, are all fallen upon thee,
And God, not we, hath plagued thy bloody deed.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: So just is God to right the innocent.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: O it was the foulest deed to slay that babe,
And the most merciless that ever was heard of.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: Tyrants themselves wept when it was reported.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: No man but prophesied revenge for it.

sp.speaker: Buch.
sp.l: Northumberland then present wept to see it.

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: What? were you snarling all before I came,
Ready to catch each other by the throat,
And turn you all your hatred now on me?
Did York's dread curse prevail so much with heaven,
That Henry's death my lovely Edwards death,
Their kingdoms loss, my woeful banishment,
Could all but answer for that peevish brat?
Can curses pierce the clouds and enter heaven?
Why then give way dull clouds to my quick curses:
If not, by war, by surfeit die your King,
As ours by murder to make him a King.
Edward thy son which now is Prince of Wales,
For Edward my son which was Prince of Wales,
Die in his youth by like untimely violence,
Thyself a Queen, for me that was a Queen,
Outlive thy glory like my wretched self:
Long mayst thou live to wail thy children's loss,
And see another as I see thee now
Decked in thy rights, as thou art stalled in mine:
Long die thy happy days before thy death,
And after many lengthened hours of grief,
Die neither mother, wife, nor Englands Queen:
Riuers and Dorset you were standers by,
And so wast thou Lord: Hastings when my son
Was stabbed with bloody daggers, god I pray him,
That none of you may live your natural age,
But by some unlooked accident cut off.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Have done thy charm thou hateful withered hag.

sp.speaker: Qu M.
sp.l: And leave out the stay dog for thou shalt hear me
If heaven have any grievous plague in store,
Exceeding those that I can wish upon thee:
O let them keep it till thy sins be ripe,
And then hurl down their indignation
On thee the troubler of the poor worlds peace:
The worm of conscience still begnaw thy soul,
Thy friends suspect for traitors while thou livest,
And take deep traitors for thy dearest friends:
No sleep, close up that deadly eye of thine,
Unless it be whilst some tormenting dream
Affrights thee with a hell of ugly devils.
Thou elvish marked abortive rooting hog,
Thou that wast sealed in thy nativity
The slave of nature, and the son of hell,
Thou slander of thy mothers heavy womb,
Thou loathed issue of thy fathers loins,
Thou rag of honour, thou detested, etcetera

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Margaret.

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: Richard.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: I call thee not.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then I cry thee mercy, for I had thought
That thou hadst called me all these bitter names.

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: Why so I did, but looked for no reply,
O Let me make the period to my curse.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is done by me, and ends in Margaret.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thus have you breathed your curse against yourself.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: Poor painted Queen, vain flourish of my fortune
Why strewest thou sugar on that bottled spider,
Whose deadly web ensnareth thee about?
Fool fool, thou whettest a knife to kill thyself,
The time will come that thou shalt wish for me,
To help thee curse that poisonous hunch-backed toad.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: False boding woman, end thy frantic curse,
Lest to thy harm thou move our patience.

sp.speaker: Q. M .
sp.l: Foul shame upon you, you have all moved mine,

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.l: Were you well served you would be taught your duty.

sp.speaker: Q. M .
sp.l: To serve me well, you all should do me duty,
Teach me to be your Queen, and you my subjects:
O serve me well, and teach yourselves that duty.

sp.speaker: Dors.
sp.l: Dispute not with her, she is lunatic.

sp.speaker: Q. M .
sp.l: Peace Master Marquess you are malapert,
Your fire-new stamp of honour is scarce currant:
O that your young nobility could judge,
What it were to lose it and be miserable:
They that stand high have many blast to shake them,
And if they fall they dash themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good counsel marry, learn it learn it Marquess.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: It toucheth you my Lord: as much as me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Yea and much more, but I was borne so high,
Our eyrie buildeth in the Cedars top,
And dallies with the wind, and scorns the sun.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: And turns the sun to shade, alas, alas,
Witness my son, now in the shade of death,
Whose bright outshining beams, thy cloudy wrath
Hath in eternal darkness folded up:
Your eyrie buildeth in our eyrie's nest,
O God that seest it, do not suffer it:
As it was won with blood, lost be it so.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Have done for shame, if not for charity.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: Urge neither charity nor shame to me,
Uncharitably with me have you dealt,
And shamefully by you my hopes are butchered,
My charity is outrage, life my shame,
And in my shame, still live my sorrows rage.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Have done.

sp.speaker: Q. M .
sp.l: O Princely Buckingham, I will kiss thy hand
In sign of league and amity with thee:
Now fair befall thee and thy Princely house,
Thy garments are not spotted with our blood,
Nor thou within the compass of my curse.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Nor no-one here, for curses never pass
The lips of those that breath them in the air.

sp.speaker: Qu. M .
sp.l: I will not believe but they ascend the sky,
And there awake gods gentle sleeping peace.
O Buckingham beware of yonder dog,
Look when he fawns, he bites, and when he bites,
His venom tooth will rankle thee to death,
Have not to do with him, beware of him:
Sin, death and hell, have set their marks on him,
And all their ministers attend on him.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What doth she say my Lord: of Buckingham?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Nothing that I respect my gracious Lord.

sp.speaker: Qu. M.
sp.l: What doest thou scorn me for my gentle counsel,
And sooth the devil that I warn thee from:
O but remember this another day,
When he shall split thy very heart with sorrow,
And say poor Margaret was a prophetess:
Live each of you the subjects of his hate,
And he to your, and all of you to Gods.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: My hair doth stand on end to hear her curses.

sp.speaker: Ryu.
sp.l: And so doth mine, I wonder she is at liberty.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I cannot blame her by gods holy mother,
She hath had too much wrong, and I repent
My part thereof that I have done.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I never did her any to my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But you have all the vantage of this wrong.
I was too hot to do somebody good,
That is too cold in thinking of it now:
Marry as for Clarence he is well repaid,
He is franked up to fatting for his pains,
God pardon them that are the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Ryu.
sp.l: A virtuous and a Christian-like conclusion,
To pray for them that have done scathe to us.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So do I ever being well advised,
For had I cursed, now I had cursed myself.

sp.speaker: Cates.
sp.l: Madam his Majesty doth call for you,
And for your Grace, and you my noble Lord:

sp.speaker: Qu
sp.l: Catesby we come, Lords will you go with us.

sp.speaker: Ry.
sp.l: Madam we will attend your grace.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I do the wrong, and first began to brawl
The secret mischiefs that I set abroach,
I lay unto the grievous charge of others:
Clarence whom I indeed have laid in darkness,
I do beweep to many simple gulls:
Namely to Hastings, Darby, Buckingham,
And say it is the Queen and her allies,
That stir the King against the Duke my brother.
Now they believe me, and withal whet me,
To be revenged on Ryuers, Vaughan, Gray:
But then I sigh, and with a piece of scripture,
Tell them that God bids us do good for evil:
And thus I clothe my naked villainy,
With old odd ends stolen out of holy writ,
And seem a Saint when most I play the Devil:
But soft here come my executioners.
How now my hardy stout resolved mates,
Are you now going to dispatch this deed.

sp.speaker: Execu.
sp.l: We are my Lord, and come to have the warrant,
That we may be admitted where he is.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It was well thought upon, I have it here about me,
When you have done repair to Crosby place;
But sirs; be sudden in the execution,
Withal, obdurate, do not hear him plead,
For Clarence is well spoken, and perhaps,
May, move your hearts to pity if you mark him.

sp.speaker: Exec.
sp.l: Tush fear not my Lord: we will not stand to prate,
Talkers are no good doers be assured:
We come to use our hands, and not our tongues.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Your eyes drop millstones when fools eyes drop tears,
I like you lads, about your business.

sp.speaker: Brok.
sp.l: Why looks your grace so heavily today?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: O I have past a miserable night,
So full of ugly sights, of ghastly dreams,
That as I am a christian faithful man,
I would not spend another such a night,
Though it were to buy a world of happy days,
So full of dismal terror was the time.

sp.speaker: Brok.
sp.l: What was your dream, I long to hear you tell it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Methought I was embarked for Burgundy,
And in my company my brother Glocester,
Who from my cabin tempted me to walk,
Upon the hatches thence we looked toward England,
And cited up a thousand fearful times,
During the wars of York and Lancaster:
That had befallen us, as we pact along,
Upon the giddy footing of the hatches:
Methought that Glocester stumbled, and in stumbling,
Stroke me that thought to stay him over board,
Into the tumbling billows of the maine.
Lord, Lord, methought what pain it was to drown,
What dreadful noise of waters in my ears,
What ugly sights of death within my eyes:
Methought I saw a thousand fearful wrecks,
Ten thousand men, that fishes gnawed upon,
Wedges of gold, great anchors, heaps of pearl,
Inestimable stones, unvalued Jewels,
Some lay in dead men's skulls, and in those holes,
Where eyes did once inhabit, there were crept
As it were in scorn of eyes reflecting gems,
Which wooed the slimy bottom of the deep,
And mocked the dead bones that lay scattered by.

sp.speaker: Brok.
sp.l: Had you such leisure in the time of death,
To gaze upon the secrets of the deep?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Methought I had, for still the envious flood
Kept in my soul, and would not let it forth,
To seek the empty vast and wandering air,
But smothered it within my panting bulk,
Which almost burst to belch it in the sea.

sp.speaker: Brok.
sp.l: Awaked you not with this sore agony.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O no, my dream was lengthened after life,
O then began the tempest to my soul,
Who past methought the melancholy flood,
With that grim ferryman, which Poets write of,
Unto the kingdom of perpetual night:
The first that there did greet my stranger soul,
Was my great father in law renowned Warwicke,
Who cried aloud what scourge for perjury.
Can this dark monarchy afford false Clarence,
And so he vanished, then came wandering by,
A shadow like an angel in bright hair,
Dabbled in blood, and he squawked out aloud,
Clarence is come, false, fleeting, perjured Clarence,
That stabbed me in the field by Teuxbery:
Seize on him furies, take him to your torments,
With that methought a legion of foul fiends
Environed me about, and howled in mine ears
Such hideous cries, that with the very noise
I trembling, waked, and for a season after
Could not believe but that I was in hell,
Such terrible impression made the dream.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: No marvel my Lord: though it affrighted you,
I promise you, I am afraid to hear you tell it.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O Brokenbury I have done those things,
Which now bear evidence against my soul
For Edwards sake, and see how he requites me.
I pray thee gentle keeper stay by me,
My soul is heavy, and I fain would sleep.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I will my Lord: God give your Grace good rest,
Sorrow break seasons, and reposing hours
Makes the night morning, and the noontide night,
Princes have but their titles for their glories,
An outward honour, for an inward toil,
And for unfelt imagination,
They often feele a world of restless cares:
So that betwixt their titles and low names,
There is nothing differs but the outward fame.
In Gods name what are you, and how came you hither?

sp.speaker: Execu.
sp.l: I would speak with Clarence, and I came hither on my legs.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Yea, are you so brief.

sp.speaker: 2. Exe.
sp.l: O sir, it is better to be brief than tedious,
Show him our commission, talk no more.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: I am in this commanded to deliver
The noble Duke of Clarence to your hands,
I will not reason what is meant hereby,
Because I will be guiltless of the meaning:
Here are the keys, there sits the Duke asleep,
I will to his Majesty, and certify his Grace,
That thus I have resigned my charge to you.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: Do so, it is a point of wisdom.
What shall I stab him as he sleeps?
No then he will say it was done cowardly
When he wakes.
When he wakes,
Why fool he shall never wake till the judgment day.
Why then he will say, we stabbed him sleeping.
The urging of that word Judgment, hath bred
A kind of remorse in me.
What art thou afraid.
Not to kill him having a warrant for it, but to be damnd
For killing him, from which no warrant can defend us.
Back to the Duke of Glocester, tell him so.
I pray thee stay a while, I hope my holy humour will
Change, it was wont to hold me but while one would tell.
How doest thou feele thyself now?
Faith some certain dregs of conscience are yet with in me.
Remember our reward when the deed is done.
S'wounds he dies, I had forgot the reward.
Where is thy conscience now?
In the Duke of Glocesters purse.
So when he opens his purse to give us our reward,
Thy conscience flies out.
Let it go, there is few or none will entertain it,
How if it come to thee again?
I will not meddle with it, it is a dangerous thing,
It makes a man a coward: A man cannot steal,
But it accuseth him: he cannot swear, but it checks him:
He cannot lie with his neighbour's wife, but it detects
Him. It is a blushing shamefast spirit, that mutinies
In a man's bosom: it fills one full of obstacles,
It made me once restore a purse of gold that I found,
It beggars any man that keeps it: it is turned out of all
Towns and Cities for a dangerous thing, and every
Man that means to live well, endeavours to trust to
To himself, and to live without it.
S'wounds it is even now at my elbow persuading me
Not to kill the Duke.
Take the devil in thy mind, and believe him not,
He would insinuate with thee to make thee sigh.
Tut, I am strong in fraud, he cannot prevail with me,
I warrant thee.
Spoke like a tall fellow that respects his reputation.
Come shall we to this gear.
Take him over the costard with the hilts of thy sword,
And then we will chop him in the malmsey But in the next room.
O excellent device, make a sop of him.
Hark he stirs, shall I strike.
No, first let us reason with him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Where art thou keeper, give me a cup of wine.
You shall have wine enough my Lord: anon.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: In Gods name what art thou.
A man as you are.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: But not as I am, royal.
Nor you as we are, loyal.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thy voice is thunder, but thy looks are humble.
My voice is now the Kings, my looks mine own.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: How darkly, and how deadly doest thou speak:
Tell me who are you, wherefore come you hither?

sp.speaker: AM.
sp.l: To, to, to.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: To murther me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Aye.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: You scarcely have the hearts to tell me so,
And therefore cannot have the hearts to do it.
Wherein my friends have I offended you?
Offended us you have not, but the King.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I shall be reconciled to him again.
Never my Lord: therefore prepare to die.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Are you called forth from out a world of men
To slay the innocent? what is my offence.
Where are the evidence that do accuse me:
What lawful quest have given their verdict up
Unto the frowning Judge, or who pronounced
The bitter sentence of poor Clarence death,
Before I be convict by course of law?
To threaten me with death, is most unlawful:
I charge you as you hope to have redemption,
By Christs dear blood shed for our grievous sins,
That you depart and lay no hands on me,
The deed you undertake is damnable.
What we will do, we do upon command.
And he that hath commanded, is the King.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Erroneous Vassal, the great King of Kings,
Hath in the tables of his law commanded,
That thou shalt do no murder, and wilt thou then
Spurn at his edict, and fulfil a man's?
Take heed, for he holds vengeance in his hands,
To hurl upon their heads that break his law.
And that same vengeance doth he throw on thee,
For false forswearing, and for murder too:
Thou didst receive the holy sacrament,
To fight in quarrel of the house of Lancaster.
And like a traitor to the name of God,
Didst break that vow, and with thy treacherous blade,
Unripped the bowels of thy sovereign's son.
Whom thou wert sworn to cherish and defend.
How canst thou urge Gods dreadful Law to us,
When thou hast broke it in so dear degree?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Alas, for whose sake did I that ill deed,
For Edward, for my brother, for his sake:
Why sirs, he sends ye not to murder me for this,
For in this sin he is as deep as I:
If God will be revenged for this deed,
Take not the quarrel from his powerful arm,
He needs no indirect, nor lawless course,
To cut off those that have offended him.
Who made thee then a bloody minister,
When gallant springing brave Plantagenet,
That Princely Novice was stroke dead by thee?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: My brothers love, the devil, and my rage.
Thy brothers love, the devil and thy fault
Have brought us hither now to murder thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O if you love my brother, hate not me,
I am his brother, and I love him well:
If you be hired for meed, go back again,
And I will send you to my brother Glocester,
Who will reward you better for my life,
Than Edward will for tidings of my death.
You are deceived, your brother Glocester hates you.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O no, he loves me, and he holds me dear,
Go you to him from me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Aye, so we will.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Tell him, when that our princely father York,
Blessed his three sons with his victorious arm:
And charged us from his soul, to love each other,
He little thought of this divided friendship.
Bid Glocester think of this, and he will weep.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Aye, milestones as he lessoned us to weep.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: O do not slander him for he is kind.
Right as snow in harvest, thou deceivest thyself,
It is he hath sent us hither now to slaughter thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: It cannot be, for when I parted with him,
He hugged me in his arms, and swore with sobs,
That he would labour my delivery.
Why so he doth, now he delivers thee,
From this worlds thraldom, to the joys of heaven,
Makes peace with God, for you must die my Lord:

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Hast thou that holy feeling in thy soul,
To counsel me to make my peace with God;
And art thou yet to thy own soul so blind,
That thou wilt war with God, by murdering me?
Ah sirs, consider, he that set you on
To do this deed, will hate you for this deed.
What shall we do?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Relent, and save your souls.
Relent, it is cowardly and womanish.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Not to relent, is beastly, savage, devilish,
My friend, I spy some pity in thy looks:
O if thy eye be not a flatterer,
Come thou on my side, and entreat for me,
A begging Prince, what beggar pities not?
Aye thus, and thus: if this will not serve,
I will chop thee in the malmsey But, in the next room.
A bloody deed, and desperately performed,
How fain like Pilate would I wash my hand,
Of this most grievous guilty murder done.
Why doest thou not help me,
By heavens the Duke shall know how slack thou art.
I would he knew that I had saved his brother.
Take thou the fee, and tell him what I say,
For I repent me that the Duke is slain.
So do not I, go coward as thou art:
Now must I hide his body in some hole,
Until the Duke take order for his burial:
And when I have my meed I must away,
For this will out, and here I must not stay.

div2.stage: Enter King, Queene, Hastings, Ryuers, Dorcet, &c.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: So, now I have done a good days work,
You peers continue this united league,
I every day expect an Embassage
From my redeemer to redeem me hence:
And now in peace my soul shall part from heaven,
Since I have set my friends at peace on earth:
Riuers and Hastings, take each others hand,
Dissemble not your hatred, swear your love.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: By heaven, my heart is purged from grudging hate,
And with my hand I seal my true hearts love.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: So thrive I as I truly swear the like.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Take heed you dally not before your King,
Lest he that is the supreme King of Kings,
Confound your hidden falsehood and award
Either of you to be the others end.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: So prosper I, as I swear perfect love.

sp.speaker: Riu.
sp.l: And I, as I love hastings with my heart.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Madam, yourself are not exempt in this,
Nor your son Dorset, Buckingham nor you,
You have been factious one against the other:
Wife, love Lord: Hastings, let him kiss your hand,
And what you do, do it unfeignedly.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.l: Here Hastings I will never more remember
Our former hatred so thrive I and mine.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: This interchange of love, I here protest,
Upon my part, shall be unviolable.

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: And so swear I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Now princely Buckingham seal thou this league
With thy embracements to my wife's allies,
And make me happy in your unity.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Whenever Buckingham doth turn his hate,
On you or yours, but with all duteous love
Doth cherish you and yours, God punish me
With hate, in those where I expect most love,
When I have most need to employ a friend,
And most assured that he is a friend,
Deep, hollow, treacherous, and full of guile
Be he unto me, this do I beg of God,
When I am cold in zeal to you or yours.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: A pleasing cordial Princely Buckingham,
Is this thy vow unto my sickly heart:
There wanteth now our brother Glocester here,
To make the perfect period of this peace.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: And in good time here comes the noble Duke.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Good morrow to my sovereign King and Queen,
And Princely peers, a happy time of day.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Happy indeed as we have spent the day:
Brother we have done deeds of charity:
Made peace of enmity, fair love of hate,
Between these swelling wrong incensed peers.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A blessed labour, my most sovereign liege,
Amongst this princely heap, if any here
By false intelligence or wrong surmise,
Hold me a foe, if I unwittingly or in my rage,
Have aught committed that is hardly borne
By any in this presence, I desire
To reconcile me to his friendly peace,
It is death to me to be at enmity.
I hate it, and desire all good men's love.
First Madam I entreat true peace of you,
Which I will purchase with my duteous service.
Of you my noble Cousin Buckingham,
If ever any grudge were lodged between us.
Of you Lord: Riuers, and Lord Gray of you,
That all without desert have frowned on me,
Dukes, Earls, Lords, gentlemen, indeed of all:
I do not know that English man alive,
With whom my soul is any jot at odds,
More than the infant that is born tonight:
I thank my God for my humility.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A holy day shall this be kept hereafter,
I would to God all strifes were well compounded,
My sovereign liege I do beseech your Majesty,
To take our brother Clarence to your Grace.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why Madam, have I offered love for this,
To be thus scorned in this royal presence?
Who knows not that the noble Duke is dead,
You do him injury to scorn his corse.

sp.speaker: Ryu.
sp.l: Who knows not he is dead? who knows he is?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: All seeing heaven, what a world is this?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Look I so pale Lord: Dorset as the rest?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Aye my good Lord: and no-one in this presence,
But his red colour hath forsook his cheeks.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Is Clarence dead, the order was reversed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: But he poor soul by your first order died,
And that a winged Mercury did bear,
Some tardy cripple bore the countermand,
That came too lag to see him buried:
God grant that some less noble, and less loyal,
Nearer in bloody thoughts, but not in blood:
Deserve not worse than wretched Clarence did,
And yet go currant from suspicion.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: A boon my sovereign for my service done.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: I pray thee peace, my soul is full of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: I will not rise unless your highness grant.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Then speak at once, what is it thou demandest.

sp.speaker: Dar.
sp.l: The forfeit sovereign of my servant's life,
Who slew today a riotous gentleman,
Lately attendant on the Duke of Norfolke.

sp.speaker: Kin.
sp.l: Have I a tongue to doom my brothers death,
And shall the same give pardon to a slave?
My brother slew no man, his fault was thought,
And yet his punishment was cruel death.
Who sued to me for him? who in my rage,
Kneeled at my feet and bad me be advised?
Who spake of Brotherhood? who of love?
Who told me how the poor soul did forsake
The mighty Warwicke, and did fight for me:
Who told me in the field by Teuxbery,
When Oxford had me down, he rescued me,
And said dear brother, live and be a King?
Who told me when we both lay in the field,
Frozen almost to death, how he did lap me
Even in his own garments, and gave himself
All thin and naked to the numb-cold night?
All this from my remembrance brutish wrath
Sinfully plucked, and not a man of you
Had so much grace to put it in my mind.
But when your carters, or your waiting vassals
Have done a drunken slaughter, and defaced
The precious image of our dear Redeemer,
You straight are on your knees for pardon pardon,
And I unjustly too, must grant it you:
But for my brother, not a man would speak,
Nor I ungracious speak unto myself,
For him poor soul: The proudest of you all
Have been beholding to him in his life:
Yet none of you would once plead for his life:
O God I fear thy Justice will take hold
On me, and you, and mine, and yours for this.
Come Hastings help me to my closet, o poor Clarence,

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: This is the fruit of rashness: marked you not
How that the guilty kindred of the Queen,
Looked pale when they did hear of Clarence death?
O they did urge it still unto the King,
God will revenge it. But come let us in
To comfort Edward with our company.

div2.stage: Enter Dutches of Yorke, with Clarence Children.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Tell me good Granam, is our father dead?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: No boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Why do you wring your hands, and beat your breast,
And cry, O Clarence my unhappy son?

sp.speaker: Gerl.
sp.l: Why do you look on us and shake your head,
And call us wretches, Orphans, castaways,
If that our noble father be alive?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: My pretty Cousins, you mistake me much,
I do lament the sickness of the King:
As loath to loose him, not your fathers death:
It were lost labour, to weep for one that is lost.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Then Granam you conclude that he is dead,
The King my Uncle is to blame for this:
God will revenge it, whom I will importune
With daily prayers, all to that effect.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Peace children, peace, the King doth love you well,
Incapable and shallow innocents,
You cannot guess who caused your fathers death.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Granam we can: For my good Uncle Glocester
Told me, the King provoked by the Queen,
Devised impeachments to imprison him:
And when he told me so, he wept,
And hugged me in his arm, and kindly kissed my cheek,
And bad me rely on him as in my father,
And he would love me dearly as his child.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: O that deceit should steal such gentle shapes,
And with a virtuous vizard hide foul guile:
He is my son, yea, and therein my shame:
Yet from my dugs he drew not this deceit.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Think you my Uncle did dissemble Granam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Aye boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I cannot think it, hark what noise is this.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O who shall hinder me to wail and weep?
To chide my fortune, and torment myself?
I will join with black despair against my soul,
And to myself become an enemy.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What means this scene of rude impatience.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: To make an act of tragic violence:
Edward, my Lord, your son our King is dead.
Why grow the branches, now the root is withered?
Why wither not the leaves, the sap being gone?
If you will live, lament: if die, be brief:
That our swift-winged souls may catch the Kings,
Or like obedient subjects, follow him
To his new kingdom of perpetual rest.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Ah so much interest have I in thy sorrow,
As I had title in thy noble husband:
I have bewept a worthy husbands death,
And lived by looking on his images.
But now two mirrors of his Princely semblance,
Are cracked in pieces by malignant death:
And I for comfort have but one false glass,
Which grieves me when I see my shame in him.
Thou art a widow, yet thou art a mother,
And hast the comfort of thy children left thee:
But death hath snatched my children from mine arms,
And plucked two crutches from my feeble limbs,
Edward and Clarence, O what cause have I
Then, being but moiety of my grief,
To overgo thy plaints and drown thy cries?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Good Aunt, you wept not for our fathers death,
How can we aid you with our kindreds tears.

sp.speaker: Gerl.
sp.l: Our fatherless distress was left unmoaned,
Your widow's dolours likewise be unwept.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Give me no help in lamentation,
I am not barren to bring forth laments:
All springs reduce their currents to mine eyes,
That I being governed by the watery moan,
May send forth plenteous tears to drown the world:
O for my husband, for my eire Lord: Edward.

sp.speaker: Ambo
sp.l: O for our father, for our dear Lord: Clarence.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Alas for both, both mine Edward and Clarence.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What stay had I but Edward, and he is gone?

sp.speaker: Am
sp.l: What stay had we but Clarence, and he is gone?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What stays had I but they, and they are gone?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Was never Widow, had so dear a loss.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: Was never Orphans had a dearer loss.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Was never mother had a dearer loss:
Alas, I am the mother of these moans,
Their woes are parcelled, mine are general:
She for Edward weeps, and so do I:
I for a Clarence weep, so doth not she:
These babes for Clarence weep, and so do I:
I for an Edward weep, so do not they.
Alas, you three on me threefold distressed,
Pour all your tears, I am your sorrows nurse,
And I will pamper it with lamentations.

sp.speaker: Gl.
sp.l: Madam have comfort, all of us have cause,
To wail the dimming of our shining star:
But none can cure their harms by wailing them,
Madam my mother, I do cry you mercy,
I did not see your Grace, humbly on my knee
I crave your blessing.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: God bless thee, and put meekness in thy mind,
Love, charity, obedience, and true duty.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Amen, and make me die a good old man,
That is the butt end of a mothers blessing:
I marvel why her Grace did leave it out.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: You cloudy Princes, and heart sorrowing peers
That bear this mutual heavy lode of moan:
Now cheer each other, in each others love:
Though we have spent our harvest of this King,
We are to reap the harvest of his son:
The broken rancour of your high swollen hearts,
But lately splintered, knit, and joined together,
Must gently be preserved, cherished and kept,
Me seemeth good that with some little train,
Forthwith from Ludlow the young Prince be fetched
Hither to London, to be crowned our King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Then it be so; and go we to determine,
Who they shall be that straight shall post to Ludlow:
Madam, and you my mother will you go,
To give your censures in this weighty business,

sp.speaker: Ans.
sp.l: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: My Lord whoever journeys to the Prince,
For Gods sake let not us two stay behind:
For by the way I will sort occasion,
As index to the story we late talked of,
To part the Queen's proud kindred from the King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: My other self, my counsels consistory:
My Oracle, my Prophet, my dear Cousin:
I like a child will go by thy direction:
Towards Ludlow then, for we will not stay behind.

sp.speaker: 1. Cit.
sp.l: Neighbour well met, whither away so fast?

sp.speaker: 2. Cit.
sp.l: I promise you, I scarcely know myself.
Hear you the news abroad?
Aye, that the King is dead.
Bad news byrlady, seldom comes the better,
I fear, I fear, it will prove a troublous world.

sp.speaker: 3. Cit.
sp.l: Good morrow neighbours.
Doth this news hold of good King Edwards death?
It doth.
Then masters look to see a troublous world
No no, by Gods good grace his son shall reign.
Woe to that land that is governed by a child.
In him there is a hope of government,
That in his nonage counsel under him,
And in his full and ripened years himself,
No doubt shall then, and till then govern well.
So stood the state when Harry the sixth
Was crowned at Paris, but at nine months old.
Stood the state so? no good my friend not so
For then this land was famously enriched
With politic grave counsel: then the King
Had virtuous Uncles to protect his Grace.
So hath this, both by the father and mother.
Better it were they all came by the father,
Or by the father there were none at all:
For emulation now, who shall be nearest:
Will touch us all too near, if God prevent not.
O full of danger is the Duke of Glocester,
And the Queen's kindred haughty and proud,
And were they to be ruled, and not to rule,
This sickly land might solace as before.
Come come, we fear the worst, all shall be well.
When clouds appear, wise men put on their cloaks:
When great leaves fall, the winter is at hand:
When the sun sets, who doth not look for night:
Untimely storms, make men expect a dearth:
All may be well: but if God sort it so,
It is more than we deserve or I expect.
Truly the souls of men are full of bread:
Ye cannot almost reason with a man
That looks not heavily, and full of fear.
Before the times of change still is it so:
By a divine instinct men's minds mistrust
Ensuing dangers, as by proof we see.
The waters swell before a boisterous storm:
But leave it all to God: whither away?
We are sent for to the Justice.
And so was I, I will bear you company.

div2.stage: Enter Cardinall, Dutches of Yorke, Quee. young Yorke.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Last night I hear they lay at Northhampton.
At Stonistratford will they be tonight,
Tomorrow or next day, they will be here.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I long with all my heart to see the Prince,
I hope he is much grown since last I saw him.

sp.speaker: Qu
sp.l: But I hear no, they say my son of York
Hath almost overtaken him in his growth.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Aye mother, but I would not have it so.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Why my young Cousin it is good to grow.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Grandam, one night as we did sit at supper,
My Uncle Riuers talked how I did grow
More than my brother. I quoth my Uncle Glocester,
Small herbs have grace, great weeds grow apace,
And since methinks I would not grow so fast:
Because sweet flowers are slow, and weeds make haste.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Good faith, good faith, the saying did not hold
In him that did object the same to thee:
He was the wretchedest thing when he was young,
So long agrowing, and so leisurely,
That if this were a true rule, he should be gracious.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Why Madam, so no doubt he is.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I hope so too, but yet let mothers doubt.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Now by my troth if I had been remembered,
I could have given my Uncles grace a flout,
That should have nearer touched his growth than he did mine.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How my pretty York? I pray thee let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Marry they say, my Uncle grew so fast,
That he could gnaw a crust at two hours old:
It was full two years ere I could get a tooth.
Granam this would have been a biting jest.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I pray thee pretty York who told thee so.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Granam his nurse.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: His nurse: why she was dead ere thou wert born.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: If it were not she, I cannot tell who told me.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: A perilous boy, go to, you are too shrewd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Good Madam be not angry with the child.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Pitchers have ears.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: Here comes your son, Lord: Marquess Dorset.
What news Lord: Marquess?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Such news my Lord: as grieves me to unfold.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How fares the Prince?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Well Madam, and in health.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What is thy news then?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Lord: Riuers and Lord: Gray are sent to Pomfret,
With them, Sir Thomas Vaughan, prisoners.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Who hath committed them?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The mighty Dukes, Glocester and Buckingham.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: For what offence.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The sum of all I can, I have disclosed:
Why, or for what, these nobles were committed,
Is all unknown to me my gracious Lady.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Aye me I see the downfall of our house,
The tiger now hath seized the gentle hind:
Insulting tyranny begins to jet,
Upon the innocent and lawless throne:
Welcome destruction, death and massacre,
I see as in a map the end of all.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Accursed and unquiet wrangling days,
How many of you have mine eyes beheld?
My husband lost his life to get the crown,
And often up and down my sons were tossed:
For me to joy and weep their gain and loss,
And being seated and domestic broils,
Clean overblown themselves, the conquerors
Make war upon themselves, blood against blood,
Self against self, O preposterous
And frantic outrage, end thy damned spleen,
Or let me die to look on death no more.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come come my boy, we will to sanctuary.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I will go along with you.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You have no cause.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My gracious Lady go,
And thither bear your treasure and your goods,
For my part, I will resign unto your Grace
The seal I keep, and so betide to me,
As well I tender you and all of yours:
Come I will conduct you to the sanctuary.
sp.stage: The Trumpets sound. Enter young Prince, the Dukes of Glocester, and Buckingham, Cardinall, &c.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Prince to London to your chamber.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: . Welcome dear Cousin my thoughts sovereign,
The weary way hath made you melancholy.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: No Uncle, but our crosses on the way
Have made it tedious, wearisome, and heavy:
I want more Uncles here to welcome me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Sweet Prince, the untainted virtue of your years,
Hath not yet dived into the worlds deceit:
Nor more can you distinguish of a man,
Than of his outward show, which God he knows,
Seldom or never jumpeth with the heart:
Those Uncles which you want, were dangerous,
Your Grace attended to their sugared words,
But looked not on the poison of their hearts:
God keep you from them, and from such false friends.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: God keep me from false friends, but they were none.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: . My Lord, the Mayor of London comes to greet you.

sp.speaker: Lo:M.
sp.l: God bless your grace with health and happy days.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I thank you good my Lord: and thank you all:
I thought my mother, and my brother York,
Would long ere this have met us on the way:
Fie, what a slug is Hastings that he comes not
To tell us whether they will come, or no.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: And in good time, here comes the sweating Lord:

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Welcome my Lord: what will our mother come?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: On what occasion, God he knows, not I:
The Queen your mother and your brother York
Have taken sanctuary: The tender Prince
Would fain have come with me, to meet your Grace,
But by his mother was perforce withheld.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Fie, what an indirect and peevish course
Is this of hers? Lord: Cardinal will your grace
Persuade the Queen to send the Duke of York
Unto his Princely brother presently?
If she deny, Lord: Hastings go with him,
And from her jealous arms pluck him perforce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord: of Buckingham, if my weak oratory
Can from his mother win the Duke of York,
Anon expect him here: but if she be obdurate
To mild entreaties, God in heaven forbid
We should infringe the holy privilege
Of blessed sanctuary, not for all this land,
Would I be guilty of so deep a sin.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: You are too senseless obstinate my Lord:
Too ceremonious and traditional:
Weigh it but with the grossness of this age,
You break not sanctuary in seizing him:
The benefit thereof is always granted
To those whose dealings have deserved the place,
And those who have the wit to claim the place.
This Prince hath neither claimed it, nor deserved it,
And therefore in mine opinion, cannot have it.
Then taking him from thence that is not there,
You break no privilege nor charter there:
Oft have I heard of sanctuary men,
But sanctuary children never till now.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.l: My Lord: you shall overrule my mind for once:
Come on Lord: Hastings will you go with me?

sp.speaker: Hast.
sp.l: I go my Lord.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Good Lords make all the speedy haste you may:
Say Uncle Glocester, if our brother come,
Where shall we sojourn till our coronation?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Where it seems best unto your royal self:
If I may counsel you, some day or two,
Your highness shall repose you at the tower:
Then where you please, and shall be thought most fit
For your best health and recreation.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: I do not like the tower of any place:
Did Julius Caesar build that place my Lord?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: He did, my gracious Lord: begin that place,
Which since succeeding ages have re-edified.

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: Is it upon record, or else reported
Successively from age to age he built it?

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Upon record my gracious Lord:

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: But say my Lord: it were not registered,
Methinks the truth should live from age to age,
As it were retailed to all posterity,
Even to the general all-ending day.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: So wise, so young, they say do never live long.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: What say you Uncle?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: I say without characters fame lives long:
Thus like the formal vice iniquity,
I moralise two meanings in one word.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: That Julius Caesar was a famous man,
With what his valour did enrich his wit,
His wit set down to make his valour live:
Death makes no conquest of this conqueror,
For now he lives in fame though not in life:
I will tell you what my Cousin Buckingham.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: What my gracious Lord?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: And if I live until I be a man,
I will win our ancient right in France again,
Or die a soldier as I lived a King.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Short summers lightly have a forward spring.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Now in good time here comes the Duke of York.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Rich. of York how fares our loving brother?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Well my dread Lord: so must I call you now.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: Aye brother to our grief as it is yours:
Too late he died that might have kept that title,
Which by his death hath lost much majesty.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: . How fares our Cousin noble Lord: of York?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: I thank you gentle Uncle. O my Lord:
You said that idle weeds are fast in growth:
The Prince my brother hath outgrown me far.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He hath my Lord:

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: And therefore is he idle?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: O my fair Cousin, I must not say so.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Then he is more beholding to you than I.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: He may command me as my sovereign,
But you have power in me as in a kinsman.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: I pray you Uncle give me this dagger.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: My dagger little Cousin, withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: A beggar brother?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Of my kind Uncle that I know will give,
And being but a toy, which is no grief to give.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: A greater gift than that, I will give my Cousin.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: A greater gift, O that is the sword to it.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Aye gentle Cousin, were it light enough.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: O then I see you will part but with light gifts,
In weightier things you will say a beggar nay.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: It is too heavy for your Grace to wear.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: I weigh it lightly were it heavier.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: What would you have my weapon little Lord?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: I would, that I might thank you as you call me.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: How? York. Little.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: My Lord: of York will still be cross in talk:
Uncle your grace knows how to bear with him.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: You mean to bear me, not to bear with me:
Uncle, my brother mocks both you and me,
Because that I am little like an Ape,
He thinks that you should bear me on your shoulders.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: With what a sharpe provided wit he reasons,
To mitigate the scorn he gives his Uncle:
He prettily and aptly taunts himself,
So cunning and so young is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: My Lord: wilt please you pass along,
Myself and my good Cousin Buckingham,
Will to your mother, to entreat of her,
To meet you at the tower, and welcome you.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: What will you go unto the tower my Lord?

sp.speaker: Prin.
sp.l: My Lord: protector needs will have it so.

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: I shall not sleep in quiet at the tower.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Why, what should you fear?

sp.speaker: Yor.
sp.l: Marry my Uncle Clarence angry ghost:
My Granam told me he was murdered there.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: I fear no Uncles dead.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Nor none that live, I hope.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.l: And if they live, I hope I need not fear:
But come my Lord: with a heavy heart
Thinking on them, go I unto the tower.

div2.stage: Exeunt Prin. Yor. Hast. Dors. manet. Rich. Buck.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Think you my Lord: this little prating York,
Was not incensed by his subtle mother,
To taunt and scorn you thus opprobriously?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: No doubt, no doubt, O it is a perilous boy,
Bold, quick, ingenious, forward, capable,
He is all the mothers, from the top to toe.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Well, let them rest: Come hither Catesby,
Thou art sworn as deeply to effect what we intend,
As closely to conceal what we impart.
Thou knowest our reasons urged upon the way:
What thinkest thou? is it not an easy matter
To make William Lord: Hastings of our mind,
For the instalment of this noble Duke,
In the seat royal of this famous Isle?

sp.speaker: Cates.
sp.l: He for his fathers sake so loves the Prince,
That he will not be won to aught against him.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: What thinkest thou then of Stanley what will he?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: He will do all in all as Hastings doth.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Well then no more but this:
Go gentle Catesby, and as it were afar off,
Sound thou Lord: Hastings, how he stands affected
Unto our purpose, if he be willing,
Encourage him, and show him all our reasons:
If he be leaden, icy, cold, unwilling,
Be thou so too: and so break off your talk,
And give us notice of his inclination:
For we tomorrow hold divided counsels,
Wherein thyself shalt highly be employed.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Commend me to Lord: William, tell him Catesby,
His ancient knot of dangerous adversaries
Tomorrow are let blood at Pomfret Castle,
And bid my friend for joy of this good news,
Give Mistress Shore, one gentle kiss the more.

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.l: Good Catesby effect this business soundly.

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: My good Lord: both, with all the heed I may.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Shall we hear from you Catesby ere we sleep?

sp.speaker: Cat.
sp.l: You shall my Lord.

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: At Crosby place there shall you find us both.

sp.speaker: Buc.
sp.l: Now my Lord: what shall we do, if we perceive
William Lord: Hastings will not yield to our complots?

sp.speaker: Glo.
sp.l: Chop off his head man, somewhat we will do,
And look when I am King, claim thou of me
The Earldom of Hereford and the movables,
Whereof the King my brother stood possessed.

sp.speaker: Buc.
